definition: too far is as bad as not enough (idiom, from the Analects)
(experienced action marker)
surname Guo
to cross/to go over/to pass (time)/to celebrate (a holiday)/to live/to get along/excessively/too-
as if/(just) like/just as/still/yet
(negative prefix)/not/no
and/to reach/up to/in time for

sentences.english: But too much of a good thing isn't the only problem with contact management programs today.
sentences.chinese: 過猶不及不僅僅只是目前聯繫人管理程序的唯一問題。

sentences.english: Don´t remove too much text though or you may achieve the opposite effects instead.
sentences.chinese: 但也別刪削太多，或是達到過猶不及的程度。

sentences.english: So-called doable, everything just to need and exist.
sentences.chinese: 所謂過猶不及，一切都只爲了需要而存在。

sentences.english: Confucius has said succinctly with a "too far" to be summarized middle ground.
sentences.chinese: 孔子曾簡潔地以一句“過猶不及”來概括中庸之道。

sentences.english: All excess is a failing, but above all in personal intercourse.
sentences.chinese: 過猶不及，人際交往最忌失衡。

sentences.english: He argues that democracy can be “too much of a good thing.”
sentences.chinese: 他認爲民主可能“過猶不及。”

sentences.english: But like any other good thing, too much of it transforms it to a vice.
sentences.chinese: 但是和其他好事情一樣，過猶不及。

sentences.english: Sometimes you need to know how much is too much.
sentences.chinese: 有時候你需要知道過猶不及的道理。

sentences.english: Having made big cuts already, though, there is a risk of overplaying that card.
sentences.chinese: 不過，產量的大幅削減也帶來了過猶不及的風險。

sentences.english: Her dress is very elegant, but her hat over-eggs the pudding.
sentences.chinese: 她的裙子非常雅緻，但那頂帽子有點過猶不及。

sentences.english: You consider medicating kids with drugs like Ritalin over-parenting.
sentences.chinese: 你認爲給孩子服用類似於利他靈的藥物是過猶不及麼？

sentences.english: However, using the courseware too much is as bad as using it too little…
sentences.chinese: 然而，教學課件應用過頻，則會產生過猶不及的效果。

definition: to advance prematurely
lit. to want sth in haste, but cannot get there (idiom, from Analects); more haste, less speed/don't try to run before you can walk
to overcorrect (idiom)/to overcompensate
to plan matters/to look for a job
to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
virtue has its rewards (idiom); one good turn deserves another
to act with undue haste (idiom); eager and impatient/overhasty
see 拔苗助長|拔苗助长[ba2 miao2 zhu4 zhang3]
argumentative/quarrelsome
when things reach an extreme, they can only move in the opposite direction (idiom)
to dabble and stop (idiom); to dip into/to attempt half-heartedly/content with a smattering of knowledge
Trouble issues from the mouth (idiom). A loose tongue may cause a lot of trouble.
to pour oil on the fire (idiom); fig. to aggravate a situation/to enrage people and make matters worse
common saying/idiom
harming others for one's personal benefit (idiom); personal gain to the detriment of others
brush stroke to the side (calligraphy)/fig. side stroke/lateral thinking
